chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This section should aid you in getting ready to develop for or with OpenSCADA.

sect2.title: Setting up your development environment
sect2.para: In order to develop applications that use OpenSCADA you need some a binary distribution and optionally source code attachments or JavaDoc.
Generally the download page for ready to build stuff is at http://download.openscada.org and for repositories at http://repo.openscada.org.
The next few sections explain the different approaches one can take in order to set up your development environment.

sect3.title: The Eclipse Way
sect3.para:
The Eclipse way is a straight forward P2 repository setup. You will need to perform the following steps:
Download and Install Eclipse 3.4 or 3.5
Add the required P2 repositories http://repo.openscada.org/p2/PROJECT/RELEASE_TYPE/VERSION. So for example if you want aurora integration version 0.15.0 you will use http://repo.openscada.org/p2/aurora/I/0.15.0. If you need atlantis release 0.14.0 you use http://repo.openscada.org/p2/atlantis/R/0.14.0. Normally you need all projects in the current release or integration version.
In order to do this open the preferences and navigate to Plug-In DevelopmentTarget Platform and create a new Target Platform by clicking Add.... Start with a default target platform and add a new Software Site.
When adding the software site be sure to disable the option Include required software as seen in screen
P2 Import Settings
Set up a new target platform and add all components from the P2 repositories added in the previous step.
Optionally you can add the following plugins to your target platform as well:
Draw2D of GEF for vector based views
ECF SDK for service discovery
Your are ready to work!

sect3.title: The Maven Way

note.para: Using maven was just to painful, buggy and results where not always reproducable. So maven is no longer a fully supported way of distributing OpenSCADA. We try to support maven by converting our P2 repositories to maven 2 compliant repositories. But this might not always work as expected.

sect3.para: One word in advance: Although this section features a setup using Maven 2, it is of course also possible (with some drawbacks) to use this setup using Eclipse and the M2Eclipse Plugin (possibly also using the Eclipse IAM Plugin).
Add the maven repository http://repo.openscada.org/maven2 to your pom.xml you are basically set up.

If you want to develop using Eclipse, we have one little helper tool which might aid you a lot in adding the OSGi Bundles from your Maven repository to your target platform. In the Update Site http://repo.openscada.org/eclipse we have the Local Maven Repository Provisioner which adds all OSGi Bundles found in your local maven repository (or any other path) to the selected target platform. Although the import has to be cleared and re-added once new versions or modules are available and the maven repository has to be populated before using the plugin, it eases the use of maven in Eclipse a lot.
This only works with OSGi bundles and not with plain jar files. Although OSGi bundles might look like plain jar files!

sect2.title: Creating a first DA client application

sect3.title: Dependencies
sect3.para:
You will need the following modules and their dependencies:
org.openscada.da.client
Additionally you will need one of the following dependencies at runtime:
org.openscada.da.client.net
org.openscada.da.client.ice

sect3.title: Project setup
sect3.para: We just need a simple java project with a main method. Although other scenarios are possible we will keep it simple.

sect3.title: Sample
sect3.para: The following sample will create a new connection to an OpenSCADA DA Server (aka Hive) and subscribe to the dataitem time. It will then sleep for 10 seconds to give the data item time to trigger some updates which are printed to the console.
